metadata.case_name: Roman Catholic Mission v. State of Madras and Sri Meenakshi Sundareswaral Devasthanam
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeals Nos. 389 of 1964 and 69 of 1965

facts.text: Two blocks of land in village Vandiyur, Madurai Taluk: Melapappathu (Survey No. 45, 28.90 acres, old No. 33, 28.75 acres, 21-9 kanis) and Keelapappathu (Survey No. 78, 20.88 acres, old No. 100, 20.53 acres, 17-10 kanis). Originally in village Managiri as manyam lands held for services.
Lands subject of ancient inam granted for performance of puja in Sri Meenakshi Sundareswaral Devasthanam, Madurai.

In 1948, Revenue Divisional Officer, Madurai held inam consisted of both melwaram and kudiwaram, alienated, liable to resumption under s.44B Madras Act 2 of 1927. Order dated April 9, 1948. Lands resumed and regranted to Devasthanam.
Lands in possession of Roman Catholic Mission of St. Mary's Church, Madurai since October 1894.
Mission appealed to District Collector under s.44B(4); dismissed March 13, 1949, holding both warams.
Mission filed O.S. No.1 of 1954 in Subordinate Judge, Madurai under s.44B(2)(d) for declaration inam only melwaram. Withdrawn to District Judge.
Mission filed O.S. No.2 of 1954 questioning resumption, claiming personal inam outside s.44B, section ultra vires. Defendants: State of Madras, Devasthanam.
District Judge dismissed O.S.1/1954 (both warams); in O.S.2/1954 held personal inam, resumption invalid, granted declaration and injunction.

Appeals: A.S. 734/1954 by Mission (O.S.1); A.S. 773/1954 by State, 787/1954 by Devasthanam (O.S.2). High Court Dec 14, 1959: Reversed both warams (only melwaram, decreed O.S.1); reversed personal (resumable, dismissed O.S.2 except melwaram); upheld s.44B.

Transfers: Lands originally belonged to Mahomedans as proprietors. Theerva (rent) subject of grant to Bhattars (Archakas). Alienations began before 1861: Krishnaswamy Chettiar purchases halves of both blocks 1861-1867.
Jan 4, 1863: Chockalingam Pillai bought half Melapappathu and half Keelapappathu from Krishnaswamy for Muthuramalingam Pillai. Oct 1864 formal release.
July 18, 1867: Original proprietors sold other half Keelapappathu (less one kani) to Krishnaswamy.
June 25, 1870: Muthuramalingam usufructuary mortgage to Vairavalingam Pillai.
Dec 14, 1871: Muthuramalingam's widow sold half Melapappathu and quarter Keelapappathu to Krishnaswamy.
June 17, 1872: Krishnaswamy bought remaining one kani.
Oct 20, 1894: Roman Catholic Mission purchased greater part Melapappathu for Rs.1500 and 6500. Remaining via decree O.S.45/1895.

legal_issues.text: Whether the inam comprised both melwaram and kudiwaram or only melwaram
Whether the inam was a personal inam not liable to resumption or a service inam for the temple liable to resumption on alienation
Whether s.44B of Madras Hindu Religious Endowments Act, 1927 is ultra vires
Whether Roman Catholic Mission has acquired title by adverse possession

petitioner_arguments.text: Inam consisted only of melwaram, not kudiwaram
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Village accounts, Inam statements, pattas (Exts A-3, A-5, A-6 to A-8, A-10, A-11)

petitioner_arguments.text: Inam was personal inam to Bhattars subject to service obligation, not attached to office, alienable if service continues

S.44B ultra vires: Inam confirmed under Inam Commission, prior alienations; contract with Crown; requires Governor's judgment; forfeiture void under GOI Act 1935 s.299, Constitution Arts 31,296; discriminates non-Hindu institutions
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: 32 & 33 Vict c.29; GOI Acts 1915,1935; Constitution Arts 14,19,31,296

respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Leases (Exts B-4 to B-6, inadmissible); othi-deed A-64

respondent_arguments.text: Inam granted for office of archakas/service to temple (Devadayam), attached to office, not personal; liable to resumption on alienation
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Exts A-3, A-11 (Inam Fair Register); service puja

court_reasoning.text: Admissible documents (village accounts, pattas, Inam statements) show only melwaram (poruppu quit rent); no proof of kudiwaram inclusion. Leases inadmissible as copies.
Inam Devadayam for archaka service (puja), recorded in Bhattars as sthanikars; not personal (no Brahmadayam, hereditary); Inam Fair Register official declaration of great importance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Service inam attached to office, resumable on alienation/cessation of service

court_reasoning.text: S.44B within provincial competence (land tenures, revenue, endowments); no contract with Crown barring legislation; resumption not forfeiture; restores to temple what alienated; no discrimination.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Valid under Devolution Rules, GOI 1935 s.292, Constitution

court_reasoning.text: No limitation for Government to resume/assess inam; adverse possession unavailable against Government prerogative.

holdings.text: Inam was service inam for temple, liable to resumption under s.44B on alienation

precedents_cited.relevance: Mauje used for villages with cultivator owners; no presumption inam includes kudiwaram

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court: Inam only melwaram (favoring Mission), but service inam for temple liable to resumption under valid s.44B (favoring Devasthanam/State); no adverse possession. Civil Appeal 69/1965 (Devasthanam) fails; disposes both appeals upholding resumption of melwaram.
outcome.relief_granted: Resumption of melwaram inam and regrant to Devasthanam upheld

key_quotes.text: All admissible matter points to the conclusion that the melwaram alone was the subject of the grant.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The Inam Fair Register incorporated an official declaration which was the result of detailed inquiries... In the absence of positive and proper evidence to the contrary such declaration must possess supreme importance.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: There is no period of limitation prescribed by any law within which alone Government should exercise its prerogative of imposing assessment on land liable to be assessed with public revenue.
key_quotes.speaker: court
